I do think you missed a lot of interesting things with the speed skate.

You talked about how the angle alpha will give the ability to push harder. The thing is however that this is only when starting. When a speed skater starts he/she wants to get up to speed as quickly as possible. They do this by sort of running on the ice. They can only run on the ice if they put their skates sideways as you see in the video. This however is not actually skating. When they reach a certain speed is when they go over into skating/gliding.

This is where things get interesting because instead of pushing to the back a speed skater pushes to the side. Pushing to the back isn’t efficient because you move forward as well so a lot of power from that push to the back will get lost because the skater is moving forward. However if the skater pushes to the side that complete push can be transformed into forward moving motion.

What is also very interesting is the way a speed skater moves from side to side transferring their body weight and using that to push themselves forward. I won’t go into that deeper because this comment is already too long.

I hope I explained it so clearly. This is slightly simplified and there are a lot more interesting techniques used with speed skating. If you find this interesting I recommend watching some videos of Joey Mantia or Viktor Thorup.

2. Saying the hockey player is doing math is a bit like saying that, by typing '𝑥 + 1 = 2 → 𝑥 = 1' into Microsoft Word, I have not merely stated a simple algebraic relationship, but I also did all the math needed to cause the vector font to be rasterized at a given size and location on the display.

3. Even if the hockey player was consciously performing the enormous volume of calculation needed to achieve certain movements and balance, performing tedius calculation is not a demonstration of impressive mathematical prowess—math is about intuition, formal reasoning, abstraction, and the application of those things to rigorous deductive arguments, which constitute one of the rare examples of arguments which can properly be termed, 'proofs'.

4. 'Doing physics' is generally used to refer to the science of physics, which implies at least some awareness and use of a formalization—e.g., using muscle memory and intuition to walk is nothing like abstracting the problem of walking to a relationship between some subset of variables sufficiently inclusive to calculate some n-dimensional solution, such that the model's solution approximates the analogous actual n-dimensional value with small-enough error to achieve a chosen level of precision, nor does it resemble the testing of such a model through measurement of a single variable, fixing all other parameters to establish a control, to conduct an experiment (i.e., what 'science' actually means). For example, throwing a ball is not equivalent to modeling the mechanical implications of applying a force to a lever as a function of time and position, resultant velocity at, and angle of, release, coefficient of friction of air on the projectile, 𝘦𝘵 𝘤𝘦𝘵𝘦𝘳𝘢.

Those feats are ends in themselves, and, throughout most of history, people attached a higher value to the talents and traits required to perform them at a high level. Destin, I think you're slightly incorrect about why ice is slippery. The science says that the crystalline structure of ice means the surface molecules aren't as stable as the ones in the lattice, and this instability means they are more likely to momentarily lose adhesion - essentially turning them into molecular marbles. I don't think friction melting causes this however, and that the liquid layer exists already.

Surface H2O molecules of ice have less chemical bonds and therefore more vibrational energy, letting them behave like a liquid (and gas when detachment occurs) - this is the new leading theory as to why the water layer exists.

The more you do something, the more your brain automates. I was a figure skater for 10-ish years and never had to think about where my skate was. You learn through trial and error, and it becomes intuitive really quickly.

It’s like how babies learn to talk. You have to learn what muscles do what and how to use those muscles for whatever purpose, but eventually you don’t have to think about keeping this muscles here and moving that one there. Imagine how difficult it would be to have to think about every single movement you have to do.

It’s not as impressive as non-skaters think it is (because they aren’t skaters). It’s as intuitive as walking, but people who don’t know how to walk are going to think it’s crazy difficult.

There is a fourth kind of skates out there, but not as common. It's the bandy skates. It is similar to the hockey skates, but with somewhat flatter blade (for increased speed) compared to the hockey skates. Bandy (which is more played in Europe, Russia and Asian countries) have a larger playing field, and less tackling than hockey making it a lower paced game, but with higher speed and longer distance than hockey. There is also a difference in what protective gear is worn and the bandy stick has a flat hitting surface for hitting the ball (not puck like in hockey).

The information about the clapskate (klapschaats) isn't totally right. The explanation why we use it isn't because of more power, but it is because of the ankle stretch. A klapschaats makes the skate movement more similar to other movements like walking and cycling, which include an ankle stretch.

Also, as a hockey player... Ermm, I mean a club level superbike racer, we don't think about the physics involved with backing it into a corner either, one simply (yeah I know, one does not simply, one will half-kill ones self spectacularly) learns by repitition where the traction of a given part of a given turn's entry is, and by gearing down faster than one should and dragging the clutch more or less right, the rear tyre's resistance via the slipping clutch and engine braking, fractionally exceeds the friction between the road surface and the contact patch. This allows the bike to back in or "feint" in to use the car drifting term, and be steered from the rear with a balance of ever decreasing front brake pressure, and clutch slip. The braking trail off is a discretionary, sometimes you may need to still be trailing a little front brake sometimes not.


Likewise feathering the throttle all the while, and then going positive throttle to actually increase rear tyre spin on exit as you're standing the bike back up, gradually so that when the rear tyre hooks up once you're upright, (larger contact patch toward the sole than in the tyre shoulder increases grip suddenly) and you are shot off down the straight, is also a learned skill. Much I imagine like hockey players don't think about the physics, they feel the skate blade shaving the ice and know how it normally behaves. Need to stop later - less shave, need to stop sooner, more shave.


And... just like a bike, too much and you slide out. Too little and your slide hooks up and you sort of shoot off in an unplanned direction, and either get some airtime before gravity brings your clamping angus back down on the seat, or you highside and do the ragdoll, maybe get chewed by your bike

Even Nobel Prize Physicist Richard Feynman used the mystery of slippery ice as an example of our inability to truly explain even basic physics on a fundamental level. The idea of instantaneous water surface caused by friction is just a theory. No one is sure that that is how it works. He said:
"Why is ice slippery?” and then you’re involved with something, because there aren’t many things as slippery as ice. It’s not very hard to get greasy stuff, but that’s sort of wet and slimy. But a solid that’s so slippery? Because it is, in the case of ice, when you stand on it (they say) momentarily the pressure melts the ice a little bit so you get a sort of instantaneous water surface on which you’re slipping. Why on ice and not on other things? Because water expands when it freezes, so the pressure tries to undo the expansion and melts it. It’s capable of melting, but other substances get cracked when they’re freezing, and when you push them they’re satisfied to be solid. What about INLINE speed skating? There's a lot more variables at play. Humidity, wheel compound, wheel dimensions, wheel crowning, amount of flexibility in the frame, track material (wood w/ polyurethane, vinal, concrete, or tarmac), wheel firmness, number of wheels (usually 3 (120-125 mm) or 4 (100-110 mm)), wheel heat, wheel wear, wheel hub streingth, wheel hub material,and the number of mounting points on the frames even. That's what we have to deal with when choosing parts for inline speed skates.

This explains so much!! I tried ice skating once, and a friend showed me how. He just said, angle your blades, but never explained why so I didn't quite get it. And with stopping, I figured out that putting a blade perpendicular to your direction of travel would stop you, but I kept on falling over. That's because I kept my centre of mass was always pretty much directly over where the blade was, so when I was decelerating, my centre of mass slowed down slower than my feet did and caused me to tip. And learning that hockey players decelerate fast by tilting the blade so that one point sheers through the ice plays into that as they tilt their body to add more pressure to the blade, making it difficult a little deeper as well as preventing them from falling over or losing balance at all. Actually, a speed skate isn't flat at all! There is an ever so slight curve on the bottom of the blade. It's there for friction reduction. If you are a short tracker, you have a different curve in comparison to a long distance iceskater. When it would be completely flat there would be to much friction, but to much curve would mean you would sink into the ice more and create friction. So in every situation, you will have to find the sweat spot that fits that particular situation.

As a hockey player, you can actually control the distance of the stop by variate your pressure when you are leaning. If you are pushing a bit more, you will stop in a shorter distance, if you just yourself slide more, then the stop distance will be longer.

Muscle memory is a great help as well but if you need to "recalculate" your stop distance, then just use your musles to push a bit extra or a bit less depends on where you want to land.

On the subject of the mathematics done in the hockey player's head, I want to bring up Brian Cox' old joke; "can a chimpanzee be thought to do trigonometry?". Movement can be described by mathematics, but the "feel" that every athlete shows, definitely works by another mechanism. We refer to it as "muscle memory", but I don't think I like that term.

What about "neuroefficiency"? When all the equations have been solved again and again, maybe a "table of all the equations and their answers" is embedded into the very structure of the brain, simplified and reinforced over years of practice, to the point where the sound of an approaching hockey puck drowned in background noise and a shadow in the corner of your eye triggers a series of muscle contractions to hit the puck while most of your brain is free to continue the interview.
It turns out that the basic physics of the slipperiness of ice is more complicated than that and still not completely understood.

A deeper edge on a hockey skate is not slower. The depth of edge better correlates to how easy it is to move laterally vs. forwards and backwards. A deeper cut blade allows you to get more power into the ice, since your skates are angled as you stride. Since the deeper cut blade restricts lateral motion, more of your stride power goes into moving you forward. For goalie skates, you use a shallower cut blade, since you want to be able to move laterally more easily, but the trade-off is that it's more difficult to skate forward and backwards, which is why goaltenders use c-cuts for a large portion of their movement.

Just on hockey skates, you could add a part 2 vid. In profile there are curves that blend together. The main one being that part of a blade that has a 9 foot radius, the front and rear curves blends into it. Also where on the blade is the balance point? Different skaters may want other radii or "blend" locations or balance points. Regarding the cross section (groove), for defenders, a smaller radius may allow for more rapid direction change. But forwards may want larger radius for higher speed. But goally blades are even more artform. As the groove radius from the front is different from the main belly of the blade. You may notice goalies slide sideways across the crease which they couldn't do with a less flat blade. But they have to make very sudden pushes off the front to reverse direction.

I know this video is a little bit old, but I still hope you read this. I am an engineer and a hockey player, and I would suggest, if you liked the physics of the hockey skate look up "Pavle Bure". He was an NHL star in the 90s nicknamed the Russian Rocket because he was so fast. In his biography, some guy analyzed his skating to figure out why he was so fast, and he discovered that Pavel actually used both edges to skate forward; he would use the outside edge to "pull" and the inside edge to push, in the same stride with each leg.

Finally, about hockey players being geniuses, I doubt that. Basketball players don't really calculate every time they shoot the ball, they pretty much base it on experience force from trial and error. Same thing applies to hockey. Lots and lots of trial and error, to get the "feel" of the stop. Your brain is not really working there, its your senses.

Great video! The one thing that I noticed that wasn't there was the difference between the rock of the blades. NOT the rock of the edges but the rock of the blades. Meaning that the speed skaters, for example, have flat blades so that they get more blade on the ice for more propulsion. The hockey skates and figure skates have more of a "rock" so that, while they don't get as much power, they are able to turn much more easily whereas if you look at the speed skater's skates, they can't turn without doing a crossover.

Once again, I'm not talking about the edges of the skates, I'm talking about the rocker of the blades (think lengthwise or from the heel to toe).

not to say hockey players are dumb brutes, but the reasoning for why they aren't brutes that you stated isn't really a good reasoning. sure physically there is a ton of mathematics going on but the human brain doesn't do math to preform physical functions. The human brain does a more of trial and error process to learn the physics of a set motion/movement/action to fine tune what each attribute does to affect the outcome of the desired action and through that we learn that "doing this does that but doing this instead of that does this instead" and how much of each "that" affects each "this". it's like pouring water into a cup,you wouldn't bother trying to learn fluid dynamics,it's like trail and error to learn how to pour water and what happens with different variables. you pour too slowly and water sticks to the container and doesn't reach the cup, pour too fast and water splashes back at you. through this trial and error you learn you should pour at a medium speed.

You are mistaken, sir. It's not friction between the blade and the ice that melts the ice and allows you to glide. Rather, it is the pressure applied to the ice by the narrow blade that melts the ice, thus creating the thin layer of water.

Remember, water expands when it freezes. Thus, applying pressure to it will unfreeze it. Pressure = force/area. The surface area of the blade is tiny, thus the pressure applied to the ice by a skater standing on skates is huge. This is how the ice melts.

You should also bring up the fact that ice is the only "normal" substance in the world that would allow "skating" motion to occur due to melting the ice under the skate. You cannot skate on any other pure substances. "Skating is made possible by friction" is only part of the story at best. If you don't know this already, google phase diagram of pure substances, and then google phase diagram of water. Water is the only substance (at least that I know) in the world that, while holding temperature constant, would change into liquid phase under higher pressure. This is why that film of liquid would exist between skate blade and ice in the first place. Under normal conditions, the ice would just be in the skating rink minding it's own business. When the skate blade hits the top of the ice surface with a person's body weight leaning on it, it applies localized pressure at the skate blade contact point. It would then melt the contacting ice surface due to higher pressure, creating a film of liquid, thus allowing skates to slip on the ice.

Skating offers a great opportunity for explaining centripetal acceleration. You oversimplified how the speed skates actually work. The angling rearward edge pushing ONLY applies at the start going from zero to low speeds. As a skater gains speed, their edge angle for pushing shifts to being almost parallel to travel direction, and push force direction shifts to very near 90º to travel direction. The faster you go the less you can gain speed with a rearward push. So at speed, a skater must redirect their power push to go outward at 90º to the travel direction, in order to get any kind of a speed boost in the forward direction.
So, how is this possible for a 90º lateral push to accelerate you forward? It's because of centripetal acceleration. Once at speed every, push stroke of a skater carves an ARC on the ice, which means they travel along on series of alternatingly opposite gradual curved arcs with each opposing leg's push. During the lateral push phase of the stroke, the skater's body mass gets laterally shifted toward the center of the skate's curving arc path. By rolling on an arc path while also laterally pushing the body's mass closer to the center of that arc, this defines a a centripetal acceleration, and it is why the skater gains speed, without any of their push force being directed rearward.

The hockey stride is incorrect because when you reach max stride velocity, you transition to a speed skating style. Most players will not get that fast in an average game so skates are designed to take advantage of acceleration instead of top end speed. But, if you see someone getting blown past half way down the ice, it is because he does not know that he needs to transition to a speed skating stride when they cannot accelerate anymore by essentially running on your toes on the ice. Too bad some many people teach kids to skate incorrectly these days.

The hockey explanation isn't entirely accurate. Because of the radius-cut method used when sharpening, the hockey blade actually has three edges. The left and right edge are the first two, as stated in the video. However, when you combine these two edges on the ice — in other words when the blade is perpendicular to the ice — you have what they call the "third edge." This edge allows the player to glide across the ice for a brief period of time before bending the ankle to begin the process of digging in one of the edges into the ice in order to stop. (You can see them using it in the slow-mo clips sections.)

I'm rather surprised the hockey player they interviewed didn't say as much, since coaches teach players about the third edge when playing in pee-wees. A lot of coaches even go as far as creating exercises for the players to feel for it, so as to have better control during drills.

Dustin, great informative video as always, but a slight correction.  Relatively recent research (2012) has shown that the pressure and friction melting model for why ice is slippery is actually incorrect.  it had been assumed to be true since the 1800's as the theory is sound, but it turns out an ice skater doesn't exert enough pressure to melt the top layer of ice, and even the combination between the pressure and the friction isn't enough energy to cause a water cushion we've always assumed to be there. 

In then end  two scientists named Professor Yoshinori Furukawa and Associate Professor Gen Sazaki at Hokkaido University’s Institute of Low Temperature Science discovered what they ace calling a quasi-liquid layer (QLL) that naturally forms around ice where water molecules vibrate at high frequency regardless of temperature due to friction or pressure. It totally changes the perception on why ice is slick and explains why it remains slippery even at extremely low temperatures where much more energy would be required to cause friction or pressure melting.  It's pretty cool when you think about it  (pun intended).  Sazaki does point out that the idea of a QLL was first proposed by Michael Faraday in 1842  a name I'm sure you're familiar with.  

Here's a link to an article on the research if your interested. (http://phys.org/news/2012-01-hidden-nanoworld-ice-crystals-revealing.html)

It's worth mentioning that hockey skate blades also have a radius from toe to heel as well known as a rocker that can be adjusted by profiling/contouring.  Generally speaking the larger the radius - more of the blade contacts ice which improves speed but reduces agility or "shiftyness".  The opposite is true with a smaller radius, you may not have the best top speed but you can turn on a dime.

I’m pretty sure friction melting has virtually no effect (or at least - it is not the dominent mechanism) on the mechanism of ice skating – Ice has a thin layer of liquid (quazi liquid) layer on it’s surface as a result of thermodynamic equilibrium with the air, this layer thickness may increase due to the fact that ice is never made out of pure water which mean solutes will always be present on its surface at high concentration, lowering even more it’s melting temperature.. Combined with the low roughness of the skating surface we get very low kinetic and static friction coefficients. In addition, ice is a porous material with a relatively low fracture toughness, making it easy to brake any small roughness features on its surface by the skating blades…

I noticed that during the part in which you were talking about speed skating ( 8:20 )you only mentioned friction melting is right, but not complete. Another reason for the thin water layer is the change in pressure on the ice. There exists a chemical balance there between liquid water and solid water (Ice). When applying pressure, the conditions of the chemical balance change in that way, that the substance ( condition) which requires less volume will be produced. 
Liquid water has a higher density than ice and therefore requires less volume.

Where did you get the information on “friction melting?” I learned that the reason skates slide so well on ice isn’t from the friction, but from the pressure exerted on the ice by the skater’s weight concentrated on the small surface area of the blade. At the end, the arms out  is literally the same as the explanation of increasing angular momentum. Arms out= mass further out = more inertia. Great video, along with many others.  I am happy to have discovered your channel.  Only one thing from right at the end, when you say the ice is melted by the friction of the skate.  It is pressure not friction that melts the ice as can be demonstrated by pushing to ice cubes together (and then releasing pressure to allow them to freeze together).  This is also why a vehicle (say a jack-knifed semi-truck) will sometimes, when stopped on an icy slope, start moving again with the slightest provocation after its own weight temporarily melts a thin film under the tires.  I have had this happen with my car from shutting the door after I parked and got out.  The door's momentum started the car sliding several inches sideways down a slight incline.  Thankfully I was on the uphill side.

Then he absorbs the impact in his legs, and springs into a different direction.  This explains how goalies eat so much snow sometimes, and why snowing the goalie is disrespectful. The amount of snow thrown can be controlled by where the player is on his rockered blade.

Hey, so I'm actually an ice dancer (a type of figure skating), and a huge part of ice dance is our ability to turn while on the ice. To turn on the ice and get credit for the turns, we have to turn on a very specific part of the blade (depending on the turn, but often right behind the ball of the foot), and make sure both that absolutely no snow flies up from the blade (opposite what the hockey player's stop did) and that our entrance and exit edges are clean (i.e. the curvature of the path of our blade on the ice before and after the turn is well-defined and constant. If you can still meet up with Glen, I'd recommend you ask him to show you rockers, counters, brackets, and choctaws. Be sure to look at his tracing after he does the turns, because what you see might look strange and counterintuitive.

Actually, "friction melting" is not what causes ice to be slippery. It's actually "compression melting". It's thermodynamics. Look at a water phase diagram. Water is one of the few materials that expands when it freezes, and melts when compressed. Using "friction melting" to reduce friction is a paradox, because the more melting you have, the less friction (and melting) you get. Put another way, it would take more drag to create less drag. And ice wouldn't be slippery when standing still.

Interesting. With roller blades a long jump is performed with a similar concept. We convert the angular momentum of the wheels into angular momentum of the boot by tipping up onto the forward wheel at a fast enough pace to stop the rotation of the wheel. Then we convert that angular momentum in the boot into linear momentum to launch us forward using some of that energy to spring upward. Then again on landing we plant with the forward wheel and roll the boot back, the moment the back wheel touches down it all changes back into angular momentum of the wheels.

Biggest mistake a newbie makes is to land on all four wheels which causes the angular momentum to shift to your center of gravity. Hilarity ensues when that happens.

I don't think athletes have to be physics geniuses to be good at their sport. They need to have some level of insight into what they're doing to get better, but it's all mostly feeling what you're doing. Muscle memory over memorizing equations. That hockey player can stop where you ask him to because he has done it thousands of times to the point that he doesn't have to think much about it at all.
